update.description:
This is the fifth of the pull requests intended to replace an earlier pull request. The purpose of this series of pull requests is to do more removal of boost from sdformat. Each branch builds upon the last one, so we'll end up with a giant octopus merge in the end.  Note that this PR is requesting to be merged into remove-boost-5 so we only see the differences on this branch.  However, the ultimate goal is to get this onto default.

This particular PR does some miscellaneous cleanup in the tree, removing some parts of boost while we are at it.


* Get rid of BOOST_ASSERT.

    Instead, make SDF_ASSERT throw an exception.  This is different
    behavior than what BOOST_ASSERT does by default, but it makes
    more sense for a library to throw an exception rather than
    abort the whole program.

* Remove include of unused boost version.hpp header.

* Remove winGetEnv.

    The same thing can be accomplished just by calling std::getenv,
    which Windows implements.

* Deal with Windows in a slightly nicer way.

    We can get rid of the #ifdef and the resulting weirdness in
    the function signature just by adding (void)_color inside
    the function body.

* Replace uses of boost in SDF.cc with our own versions.

* Use our version of trim in Param.cc
update.title: Remove boost - Misc (PR 5/5)

update.title: Remove boost - Misc (PR 5/5)

content.raw: Now that pull request #314 has been merged, there are conflicts here
content.html: Now that pull request #314 has been merged, there are conflicts here

content.raw: From what I've been reading, on Windows, GetEnvironmentVariable and std::getenv work equivalently at process startup time.  The difference comes at run-time, where calling std::getenv will not see changes to the environment after the process is started: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/631664/accessing-environment-variables-in-c/631717#631717 .  I don't know how much we care about that use-case, but that would seem to be a downside to using it.
content.html: From what I've been reading, on Windows, GetEnvironmentVariable and std::getenv work equivalently at process startup time. The difference comes at run-time, where calling std::getenv will not see changes to the environment after the process is started: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/631664/accessing-environment-variables-in-c/631717#631717 . I don't know how much we care about that use-case, but that would seem to be a downside to using it.

content.raw: Using the same function sounds good to me. I don't understand enough to know why we had a separate function though. All tests are passing on windows, but I wonder if any of them is using this function.
content.html: Using the same function sounds good to me. I don't understand enough to know why we had a separate function though. All tests are passing on windows, but I wonder if any of them is using this function.

content.raw: I just synced `remove-boost-5` with `default` and now there are conflicts here, do you mind fixing them?
content.html: I just synced remove-boost-5 with default and now there are conflicts here, do you mind fixing them?

content.raw: Ah yeah, OK.  I didn't realize we did that along the way.  I'll update it.
content.html: Ah yeah, OK. I didn't realize we did that along the way. I'll update it.

content.raw: Yeah, as far as I can tell from the documentation (and the CI), Windows implements getenv just like Unix does, so there is no need for a separate function.
content.html: Yeah, as far as I can tell from the documentation (and the CI), Windows implements getenv just like Unix does, so there is no need for a separate function.

content.raw:
Interesting, Gazebo also has a special getenv because of windows:

https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/1626/windows-common-update-part4/diff
content.html:
Interesting, Gazebo also has a special getenv because of windows:

https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/1626/windows-common-update-part4/diff
